>So said Kris Henderson on 4/18/2003 --------------------
>> -----Original =
Message-----
>> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...] 
>> Tha=
t's an interesting approach. It's slightly different from 
>> what I would =
do.
>
> Interesting in a good way?  :)

No value judgment implied. :)

>> W=
hy a MockService? Is the service not the thing you're 
>> testing? 
>
>The =
reason I created a MockService class is because I wanted to test the
>code =
in the abstract class and to get an instance of the abstract class
>I need =
a concrete class.  Is a mock object the correct terminology in
>this case?
=

I don't suppose it matters much, but no, I wouldn't call that a "mock". It=
's just an implementation of the abstract class.

>> I always get nervous w=
hen I have to mock the thing 
>> I'm testing. Since you're testing the even=
t source, I would 
>> recommend rewriting this test so that the event sourc=
e you 
>> test is an actual event source, and not some subclass 
>> (howeve=
r trivial) of it.
>
>The original intent of my test was to verify that an e=
vent is fired when
>certain methods in the abstract class are called and th=
at the event
>object contained the correct data.  Would that be considered =
testing the
>event source?

Yes, but...

>> For example: factor out the eve=
nt source from the abstract 
>> class, then test the event source on its ow=
n.
>
>I like this idea.  I'll have to take a look at the design to see how =
I
>can work it in.

... this is the approach I would take.
